characters: ANOTHER DEN-LIKE ROOM WITH A VIEW
RECORD CYCLE WILL CAUSE BIT OVERLOAD. DO YOU WISH TO PROC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cuts, seductive angles: 70 hot-air balloons rise ov a vast, green corporate campus. Their mylar skins are  imprinted with Outpost '98 logos; their gondolas are dres in Outpost-colored bunting. 18,000 Outpost employees cheer. They're spread out over  rolling lawns, amid Arabian tents and costumed Acrobats.  Over the balloon-dotted sky, the graphic re-appears: "The coolest thing?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the beverages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. OUTPOST OFFICE - DAY (CONTINUE TITLES & MUSIC) A Programmer sits in his handsome office, forested landsc out the window. The screen says: DARYL, M.I.T. '95

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary always makes sure we've got the  coolest stuff to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUMP CUTS of tall refrigerators: Snapples, Cokes, Fruitop Zaps, Jolts, Barques & Sprites are lined-up behind gl doors. "The coolest thing?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowing your work means something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. OUTPOST CAMPUS - DAY (CONTINUE TITLES & MUSIC) A 24-year-old Korean-American Girl sits at the edge of a  plashing, post-modern fountain. DIANA, STANFORD '97

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowing everywhere in the world,  this is the software people use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE of world capitals & remote places: Stockbroke Farmers, News Anchors & Students, CEO's & Eskimos Outpost '98, or log-on with Outpost Internet Traveler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 years ago, Gary had an idea, that's  all he had. And now the company's  bigger than IBM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the last shot (a Ghetto Kid uses Outpost Word in the library): "The coolest thing?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the people. Which is weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. COFFEE HOUSE/TERRACE - DAY (CONTINUE TITLES & MU A Programmer sits with two colleagues, drinking lattГ©s a the edge of Lake Washington. MITCH, BERKELEY, '98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big companies are s'posed to be  impersonal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE: Programmers play competitive games at an Outpost picnic; Toddlers play on computers in an Outpost Day Care Center; Geeks confer at a diagram-covered whiteboard;  Employees listen/dance to the Seattle band we've been hea on-stage, at the Outpost '98 launch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's this myth that doing a start- up is cooler. But there's no community  with a start-up. No permanence.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: One of Mitch's colleagues is nodding. DONNY, HARVARD, '97

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It bums me out when the media say  we're cultish, or whatever. Why?  'Cause we care about each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donny didn't mean to sound so mushy. Nobody knows where t look for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Love you too, bro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they laugh: "The coolest thing?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what's not cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How Gary gets this superbad rap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE of magazine covers (Newsweek, Vanity Fair, WIRED) featuring Gary Boyd. They say, eg: "Who Owns Cyberspace?" a Time cover, he's composited by the Capitol Dome: "ROBBE BARON OR VISIONARY? Outpost's Antitrust Woes"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's this prejudice against super- smart people. People like Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GARY (early 40's) reads a statement before a Congressiona Sub-Committee. His voice is pleasant but firm:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kid working in his garage can create  the next Outpost, the new IBM. All  it takes is a great idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bloated Senator looks hostile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why nobody can have a monopoly  in a business built on ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we watch, CAMERA pulls back from the screen on which t movie is being projected. REVERSE INTO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over an audience of 40 or so computer students we read:

dialogues.speaker: STANFORD UNIVERSITY
dialogues.text: We pick out MILO CONNOR, watching keenly. He's 21: clear- eyed, alive, innocent. He sits with his best friend, TEDD CHIN, third-generation Chinese-American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coolest? Gary. He's like you or  me. If we happened t'be insanely  rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some appreciative laughter in the auditorium. But behind  Milo, LARRY LINDHOLM squirms in his seat. He whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me? It's Seattle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Starting to get nauseated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIAN BISSEL, in front of Milo, twists in his seat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry gets up. Two Outpost Recruiters, REDMOND PRICE, 31 (gray suit) and DANNY BAYLOR, 29 (Outpost '98 golf shirt) note the walkou Danny scans headshots in a Stanford Yearbook. (On-screen  behind them we see Seattle: night streets wet-down &  shimmering; Young People entering a club; Young People  climbing Mt. Shasta.) Finding Larry's picture, Danny poin out the name to Redmond, who shrugs: unconcerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did anybody mention the beverages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The double-doors swing open (over them, a plate reads: TH HEWLITT-PACKARD AUDITORIUM) and Larry comes out.

dialogues.speaker: UP THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: ALICE POULSON, a very pretty girl of 21 (more hiply dress than the geeks) searches the hall, reading the names over the doors (NEC Communications Classroom, Toshiba Computer Lab, Mitsubishi Classroom). She spots Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still have to give 'em  refreshments laced with mind-altering  drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a fanatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Gonna wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilting down the neo-classical edifice, we read the name  etched over the entrance: WILLIAM GATES COMPUTER SCIENCE  BUILDING. We find Larry and Alice sitting on the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice? You gotta make him do the  start-up with Teddy and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Make" him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we hear Larry speak, we cut back into:

dialogues.speaker: THE AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: The lights are on. Milo & Teddy stand by a table dres Outpost bunting, laden with refreshments & giveaways: mousepads, T-shirts, caps & books with the Outpost lo them (a simple contour drawing of a frontier outpost). Wh most Students chat earnestly with Recruiters, Milo & load their plates with pizza and tortilla chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not exactly worldly, but I'm the  Secretary of State next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo puts some brownies on his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they're all throwing this --  stuff at him. Stock options. Pay  packages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spotting a book on the table, Milo picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just screwed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (that's not true) You know what he's like. He just  wants to work on stuff that's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't wanna move, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can paint anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry looks at her: you didn't answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to stay here, yeah. And I  kind of think he should be with Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: THE AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: Milo and Teddy discuss the book almost joyfully. (We see page of code: utterly indecipherable.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, nobody else can follow what  they're talking about half the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under Alice) 'Could be a condition-variable in  the locking code -- If it didn't seg  fault, first!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you shouldn't push it so hard.  About Outpost. No offense, you sound  insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it. I feel like they'd  do anything to keep their --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything? That's not even credible.  If he wants to go up there? To check  it out? I think you should encourage  him. (seeing Larry's  incredulity) It's his life. But everybody's  treating him like this -- valuable   object. You're hurting your own case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, already wearing one of the Outpost caps, effuses t Redmond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my god. I hear he actually calls  recruits sometimes. Or is that an  Urban Legend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary's running the biggest software  company in the world, Brian. He's  being harassed by the Justice  Department, and he's got a new baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room, Milo (eating chips, perusing code) reach for a napkin but unwittingly grabs some bunting. It unrav in a long TP-like streamer -- just as Danny approaches,  peering at Milo's ID tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo? I'm Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to sluff the paper off his hand; Danny holds out cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary would like to speak to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo and Teddy look at each other: right. But Danny looks like he means it. Milo's grin fades. He takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo? Gary Boyd. I'm hoping you and  your friend can come up here. We've  made some amazing strides in digital  convergence. I'd love to show them  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would? Wow. When would we come? (he waits; he looks  up) 'Think he hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny holds out two plane tickets, in 1st class folders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice examines one of the tickets almost suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how does he know that's what you  guys're working on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, Teddy & Brian are at the table with Alice &amp It's a student hang-out, with loud music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the companies know. The faculties  tell 'em. At the target schools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In exchange for endowments. They  should just drop the pretense and  name the schools after 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Teddy) I can't believe you refused a ticket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents're already freaked-out  I'm staying here. 50 miles from  Chinatown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well maybe if you told 'em how much  money you'd be making -- (to Milo) You're going up there. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it's your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Alice predicted, Milo is pleased by Larry's remark.  "Empowered." Larry smiles conspiratorially at Alice. INT. MILO & ALICE'S APARTMENT - MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT In a tidy, playfully decorated room, Alice stirs in bed,  sees the space next to her is vacant.

dialogues.speaker: TINY ROOM
dialogues.text: Milo sits at a desk, thinking, agitated, in the dim light a PC. He looks up, sees Alice in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I kind of lost it. I was  just so thrilled to be talking to  the richest, most powerful... 'Didn't  know I even cared about that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, how often do you talk to  somebody who's been on the cover of  Time. Three of four times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks her way through geek clutter (motherboards, cod manuals, Coke cans) sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of what Larry says is true.  They just clone stuff, or reverse  engineer it, and everybody gets stuck  with their inferior version cause  they --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you've gotta ask him about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her: you've gotta be kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's really a bully, he won't cop  to it, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bully? Are we talking about Gary  Boyd? Or your dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't deny it: she sees right through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a kid? And he was moving  us all over the place? I spent all  my time writing stuff on Outpost  1.0. I thought Gary Boyd was the  greatest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's not quite the same guy  anymore. Don't get your hopes too  high?

dialogues.speaker: INT. 737
dialogues.text: In the cabin, everybody types on a notebook but Milo. He  looks out the window expectantly: at the Seattle skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo comes off the plane. Danny and Redmond greet him.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. HIGHWAY/CAR
dialogues.text: Redmond drives his black Lexus 85 m.p.h. Danny leans forw from the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Couldn't convince Teddy to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's pretty tight with his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could move 'em up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just likes to write code. He's  bummed there's so much secrecy and  competition, everybody trying to own  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you mean by "everybody."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo almost blushes. He makes an awkward segue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So -- how far are we from the campus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh we're not going to the campus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond a rocky beach, buildings are cunningly carved into wooded hillside. Glass walls are framed in rich wood. The main house is 28,000 sq. ft. Then there's the guest house pool building, reception hall, library...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redmond pulls up. A discreet Guard in a Mr. Rogers cardig recognizes him. The gates swing open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull up by a Lexus SUV with a baby seat. Another Man a cardigan stands in the open front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they call him the "Houseman."  'Cause "guard" sounds too weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo just sits there, eyeing the monumental residence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be nervous. The house is the  weirdest thing about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like he knows everybody expects  him to be this worldly, colorful  zillionaire. But he's just a guy who  likes software.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo and the Houseman cross a long room with a lake view. hear music by Satie. The Craftsman furniture and lamps ar custom-made. A Cezanne hangs on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DEN-LIKE ROOM WITH A VIEW
dialogues.text: There's a Craftsman crib here, stuffed animals, another  Cezanne. Even the toys seem arranged. They enter an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat. He won't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits on a bench. He tries not to look, but his child hero is partly visible through a glass panel in the door: Gary (in a suit and tie) has an open American face. But  something goes on behind his pleasant features and self- possessed mien: his desire (or need) to solve the problem hand is so intense it makes him appear vexed -- even  vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: As Gary concentrates, two Outpost Senior Managers speak:  PHIL TATE, 40 (bald); and RANDY GRIMES, 36, (gray eyes).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried the big vaporware number,  Gary, it's no-sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we buy into their IPO? Or is  that a Justice Dept. problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no public offering. The guy  who wrote it joined some freakazoid  cult in San Luis Obispo. 'Wrote this  just to run their web site.

dialogues.speaker: ANTEROOM
dialogues.text: Gary speaks with precise hand gestures: settling the matt Phil and Randy gather their papers, and stand. They exit, nodding at Milo as they pass. Then Gary comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo? Excuse the tie. I was on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo is a little dazzled as they shake hands: such a fam- iliar face, such a big figure in his young life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now New Age music plays. They move back through the same  room, but the Cezanne has been replaced by a Hieronymus B (bodies roiling in Hell). Milo is -- puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house knows the paintings I like,  it knows my favorite music. Same for  anybody else who's in the system.

dialogues.speaker: NEXT ROOM
dialogues.text: As they walk, Milo watches a Cezanne "original" digitally configure to a Bosch, brushstrokes and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a Coke or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too shy, too nervous) Oh. No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a glass-doored refrigerator, scans a shelf with  rows of Snapples -- in alphabetical order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we started, I just hired my  smart friends. That was great. We  got a little bigger, I had to hire  smart strangers. Much harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He selects a Kiwi-Raspberry, they walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I don't get to hire anybody. But  I know you're the guy to write  Skywire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. An entire wall is taken-up by a Bosch triptyc As Gary crosses to the other side of the room, Milo stand by a table covered in art books -- hundreds of them (Sout Chinoiserie, Roy Lichtenstein...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know a lot about art, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a rumor going around, maybe  you've heard it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary heads back, carrying something spherical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more to life than computers?  I'm looking into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glancing down at the daunting display of books, Gary look vaguely afflicted. He mutters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Once I start looking into something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking up now (and much more at ease) he holds up a shin detailed metal object: model satellite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only shown this to three other  people. I bought 200, we've launched  12 so far. I keep the coordinates in  this room. (as Milo takes it,  carefully) It's left over from SDI. Reagan's  Star Wars technology? They orbit 426  miles up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low enough to relay internet traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he smiles: exactly) Among other things... We know  convergence is the real super-highway:  all the PC's, TV's, phones, etc.  linked together. Why cram it into a  cable if you can use the whole sky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning the sleek  object) Skywire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo and Gary peer at a monitor, side-by-side. Milo sips own Snapple now. Gary speaks his language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The content filer has t'be written  into the media files so bits coming  off the satellite can be read by  multiplatforms. Really, omniplatforms.  Including whatever new hardware  emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It needs a more object-oriented  language. This doesn't scale, does  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have to start practically from  scratch. But this is all you'd be  working on. No marketing meetings,  no product seminars. We can't waste  the time. Half the Valley's working  on convergence. So're media  conglomerates, cable companies, phone  companies. 'Can't finish second,  Milo. There is no second... Now what  would you like to ask me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo has a deer-in-the-headlights look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ask you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk, Milo chides himself for his reticence. Gary seems to read his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what people say, and not just  the Justice Department. We clone  ideas, inflict our second-rate  versions on the world, we haven't  done anything original since 1.0.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo's amazed by Gary's acuity. And his candor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I think that's fair? No. I'd put  some of our apps up against anybody's.  But is there some truth to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have come to a stop in a windowed entryway. Milo wat Gary keenly. Gary nods. He knits his brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get to a certain age, you  start wondering. About your legacy.  I doubt you even remember Outpost  1.0 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) Yeah? I wanna feel like I did when I  wrote that. But I'm 42, that's 100  in cyber-years. I look at you and  see the things that got me here. (the furrows deepen) But somehow got away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block of floodlit "tract mansions," Taco Bell palaces o the Valley's newly rich. Milo & Alice cross a vacant where the lights twinkle below. Their '89 Honda Civic is  parked nearby. Milo is excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If my dad'd leveled with me like  that even once... The weird thing  is, my fantasy he could somehow be  like the old Gary? It's his fantasy,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's great, Milo. I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you visit the campus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot. That's why you have to  help me decide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. You have this -- destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I wouldn't have a destiny  without you. My destiny would be  dying at 20. From eating --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bring that up. Like a different  girlfriend would'd've let you die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) You saved my life in alot of ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sweet. She kisses him. He holds onto her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not just Gary that makes you  wanna go there? 'Cause it's a big  place. You might not even see him  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd hate to think that's true. But he manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. MILO & ALICE'S APARTMENT - DAY The Honda is loaded with luggage and boxes, some of which are tied to the roof. Milo & Alice stow a final piece

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's Brian coming for the TV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prob'ly waiting by the phone for  Outpost to call. We'll leave it for  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they head back in, they see a Toyota park at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Give you guys some time alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues inside. He waits, watches Teddy cross the  sidewalk to join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You got my E-mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your phone messages. You wanna  do what you do, it's not a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that how Larry feels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh. Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brown Buick parks behind Teddy's car. As they speak, a  rumpled, 50ish MAN in an off-the-rack suit gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanted to say goodbye to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we got seed money for the  startup! A million-five!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo grins, he high-fives Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We rented a loft in Sunnyvale. (he gives Milo the  number) You know what's the bad part? We  can't talk about work anymore. We're  competitors! The venture capitalists  made us sign like 100 confidentiality  forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outpost made me sign 1,000. 'Guess  we'll find out what else we have to  talk about. Life stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace. It's awkward, but it's heartfelt. INT. MILO & ALICE'S APARTMENT - A MOMENT LATER Milo enters, reading Teddy's phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess what? They got their --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rumpled Man sits on a radiator, watching CNN on a TV, the last remaining piece of furniture. Alice enters, hold a jam jar filled water, hands Milo a business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, this is Mr. Barton from the  Justice Department. (gives Barton the  water) Sorry about the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo reads the card: Lyle Barton, Asst. Prosecutor, DOJ,  Seattle Branch Office. Milo's a little spooked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Milo. I'm here as a  friend. Or maybe a supplicant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... What's that mean again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beggar. We're at a disadvantage with  Outpost. Our experts aren't as smart  as theirs. Sometimes we can't tell  which technologies pose the threat  of a monopoly. We need a really smart  guy to help us pick our fights. I'm  taking a shot in the dark, here. I  can offer you 32,000 a year, a Buick.  I'm hoping you've got a feeling it's  the right thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiddling with the  card) It's just -- I kind of feel the need  to do something with my ability.  Create something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said: shot in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo tries to give back the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you see something there that rubs  you the wrong way? Do the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That took some fun out of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not gonna let it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him. They head out. We linger. On TV a graphic says: SAN LUIS OBISPO, CA: MASS SUICIDE - LIVE. Emergency Medical Personnel roll gurneys with bodies out of a new  Mediterranean mansion. Footage shows bodies (including a children) on bunkbeds, uniformly shod in black Nikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- ingested the fatal mixture of  sedatives crushed in apple sauce.  According to the cult's eerily  professional website, it was "time  to move on..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crane past identical, low, steel & glass buildings, a vast lawns & fir trees... Past a building under  construction... To find Redmond's Lexus, cruising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo looks out the window, Redmond gives the tour:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There're 20 buildings, I mean not  counting the Gyms, the Day Care,  etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Day Care is a Michael Graves-looking building with a cartoon-dog sculpture on its roof, ears cocked to the sky Teacher leads her little charges inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary's put millions in there. And  the people with kids? They're not  hotshot geeks, they're just payroll  clerks or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Men in suits, with briefcases, (conspicuous amid the  Geeks in jeans and T-shirts) enter Building #19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see alot of that: Department  of Justice goons snooping around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls into a lot full of Miatas, BMW's, Boxters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The logo is of inlaid stone. Redmond & Milo walk over Milo carries a box with some personal effects, including small painting. Redmond wears a photo I.D. tag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how'd you like the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Snapples were in alphabetical  order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he laughs) Well, he micro-managed the company  till it got too big... (he opens the door) 'Guess he needs to micro-manage  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the desk, a RECEPTIONIST looks up, stands to hang a  temporary ID pass around Milo's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, I'm Judith. Welcome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo smiles. Redmond uses his magnetic swipe card on an i door (a security cam is at every door); he holds the door open for Milo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk up a long carpeted hallway, past open offices w Geeks (mostly males under 30) sit at workstations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody has the same office, there's  no dumbass corporate hierarchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass a room in which Geeks play video games. Just ou it, a chubby programmer, DESI, sips a Diet Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out while you can, dude!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desi, Milo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy who was at Gary's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows deep, with mock-obeisance. Milo blushes, Redmond  laughs, he snags Milo's elbow. They walk again, passing a service hall with a Civil Defense sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best bomb shelters in America,  accessible from every building. You  gotta figure we're a major target,  right?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Up the hall, a young woman (LISA) is about to go into her office. She pauses half a second, looks at Milo, goes in. She's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. Lisa actually looked at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pass her office, they look in: she's already at h workstation, studiously avoiding their gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every geek here's got a thing for  Lisa. But that's about the biggest  reaction she's had to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shy, changing the  emphasis) She's a programmer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy graphical background, doing  design-interface for Skywire apps. (he all but winks) You'll be working with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a girlfriend, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. That's rare around here. You  know how nuns' re-married to Jesus?  'Posties are married to Outpost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome, modest office like all the others: workstatio whiteboard, window. They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your world. (pointing at the desk) Copy of Gary's book, also the audio  version, narrated by Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo puts down his box, picks up the book: The Next Highw (Gary by a highway on its cover). As we look at it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The card's encoded. Tells us who  came through the door and when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an office with a bank of monitors that play feeds from security cameras, BOB SHROT, 40, Head of Physical Securit issues Milo his swipe card. Redmond watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unauthorized entries sound like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drags the card through a sample slot, producing an  unbelievably loud, piercing EEEEEEEE. He shouts over it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you see a tailgater, report him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tailgater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kills the alarm) Somebody coming in on your swipe. (gives Milo a photo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see somebody wandering around  without ID, it's your duty to  challenge him. I don't give a shit  if you're a stock-option billionaire.  If you don't challenge, I'll have  your butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems a little -- tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geeks pull his chain cause he's non- tech. Ex-cop or something. They moon  cameras, or use ATM's as swipe cards.  The cameras're our real security so  he's a little demoralized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk, Milo watches two Hardhats roll a spool of f optic cable into the building under construction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're they building?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: #21. Way behind schedule. It's top- secret, but everybody knows it's a  digital broadcast space. They see  the dishes on top, the fiber optics  going in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary's not into fiber optics. He's  betting everything on the satellites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna survive in the software  business, you cover your bets... I  gotta say, this is the weirdest car  anybody ever requested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach a 1990 Deux Chevaux, cheap but charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Your girlfriend's an  artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blond wood, smoked glass -- a room as sleek as the Geeks lunch here are nerdy. Milo and Redmond push trays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I phoned her at your hotel, told her  about our corporate housing options.  She sounds neat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa's at a table, looking at Milo. When their eyes meet, she busies herself, placing the plates back on her tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She is. (turning away from  Lisa) She is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa passes behind them, smiles fleetingly at Milo. At a  table, Randy and Phil note the "interaction." Meantime:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Might be some friction on the  domestic front. You're expected you  to put in ridiculous hours. People've  accused us of breaking up  relationships to get their undivided  attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa moves swiftly up the hall. She looks up it and down (making sure no one's looking) before ducking into

dialogues.speaker: MILO'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: She goes to the box on Milo's desk (his personal effects) starts rooting through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redmond and Milo have eaten; Redmond stacks their plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your counselor'll fill you in on  everything else. That's who you'll  be working with almost daily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo has fed the old Skywire disks into his machine. He r a complicated screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo looks up. It's Gary. Milo is thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Just waiting for my counselor to  come by and introduce himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo's smile deepens. Gary notices the small painting (by Alice) hanging on the wall. He stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Think I should buy some originals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Do I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody said I'm just another  Philistine. With reproductions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's insane. You're ahead of your  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I told her. My wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo colors as Gary drags a second chair in front of the  screen; didn't realize he was contradicting Mrs. Boyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Thinks I'll be less of a control  freak if I have a hobby. 'Just gives  me something else to obsess about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo smiles as Gary sits down, studies the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything we can salvage from the old  code before you start fresh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo can't quite get over: Gary's his counselor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, might be one or two things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two awe-struck Geeks see Gary through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been in there like an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could work with a new switch. There  may be a few more things hidden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't spend too much time searching.  You ever vetted somebody's old code  before? (when Milo shakes his  head) It's a different skill. Stay close  to the surface. The best-hidden  secrets are in plain sight. You know  the best place to hide a leaf, right? (when Milo shakes his  head) In a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in an old (empty) Craftsman house. Through a front  window, we see Alice lead Milo up a path. As they enter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The corporate condos were as  romantic as they sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo's grinning as he takes in the house.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Windows give onto a garden with a small studio. Milo's st beaming, Alice is pleased. Till he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know he's never been anybody's  counselor before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo! What about --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures at what she hopes will be their home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, It's great. It's great! (they start to kiss,  but:) 'Think I should tell him I learned  everything using 1.0? Maybe I could  show him one of my early programs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls him back into the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: W/ MUSIC
dialogues.text: 1.) MILO types intently in his office. 2.) GARY sits with MILO at his desk, discussing code. Pan the window; we see a different pair of awed Geeks. 3.) Milo & Alice read in bed. He's reading Gary's boo 4.) MILO shows GARY one of his early programs, written on 1.0.: it's simple-looking, with some childish writing scr on it. Gary seems touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two DOJ AGENTS depose Gary. (A video-cam records his answ Two Outpost LAWYERS sit next to him. One of the Agents is reading from a document:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Infotek's urgent need to license  Outpost Office is such that we can  use it as a tool in the current  negotiation." (looks up) When you wrote the word "tool," what'd  you mean by it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary studies his copy of the E-mail. He looks vexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you think you meant by it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm confused. Am I supposed to  speculate under oath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Agent shifts in his seat. We get an idea of Gary's  negotiating skill (making the other party look unreasonab while offering nothing).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you didn't have an answer to  that question, Mr. Boyd --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("confused" again) Didn't I? Have an answer? "I don't  remember."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Agents confer. Gary sees Phil, looming outside the op door. One of the Agents sees him, too. He doesn't try to  hide his annoyance:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you wanna take a break, Mr. Boyd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary takes a manila envelope from Phil, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your protege's moving so fast we can  barely keep up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary reads the page from the envelope: computer code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is good. Who did it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Start-up not 50 miles from here.  Kid's on Prozac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should all get on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo stares at his screen, frustrated. Gary enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm going too fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply; incredulous) Too fast? At least four companies're  on the verge of workable convergence  systems, Milo, they --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catching himself, Gary trails off. He sits down, exhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even when I had a hand in every aspect  of the company I knew the one thing  you can never control is somebody's  creative process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary seems sincerely contrite. (He needn't be: Milo just  wants to please him. Besides: Milo sees he'd like to stop obsessing about convergence, to be a "worldly zillionaire engrossed in his hobbies; but, after all, what could be m engrossing than Skywire?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching into his  pocket) Take a look at this. Slightly  different approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reading the page Gary got from Phil, Milo knits his brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did this -- overnight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making me young again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN OFF a TV, where local news footage shows a mangled,  smoking BMW, post-wreck, on a lonely nocturnal highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A graduate of MIT, he was on the  antidepressant Prozac, and had been  warned not to drink and drive. (Etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa watches the news report, knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa heads up the hall, carrying a CD-ROM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo's typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're famous around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winces) I'm getting a teacher's pet rep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry about it. You've  gotta figure most people around here  were their teachers' pets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We moved around so much I barely  knew my teachers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too! Were you an Army brat or  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Something like that. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't mean to pry. I just have this  theory. Some of us who got to good  at this? We were -- escaping  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This seems to jolt her. She pales a little. What a myster girl. But this only adds to her allure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I know what you mean. I used to  spend my life wishing people could  be like computers. Least they make  sense. Sometimes you think they've  betrayed you. Like a person would.  But then you see, no, you just missed  a step. You can go back and make it  all work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This strikes a deep chord with Milo, all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to wish that. All the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're looking at each other: he gets self-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the CD-ROM) What've you got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graphical interfaces. For Skywire?  I'm s'posed to coordinate with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit. As she inserts the disk, he finds himself looki at her. On the screen, the frontier outpost we know as th logo appears. It's struck by a bolt from the sky. The out comes alive with light, music, movie-images through its  windows, a ringing phone. Finally, the word SKYWIRE burns into it. It's neat, she's really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? I ran it for lots of platforms,  ranging from the narrowest bandwidth  to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simultaneously, they reach for the mouse. Their hands tou They look at each other. Something happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sh-Show me the next one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, manipulates the mouse. He stares at the screen  strenuously, fighting the impulse to stare at Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary's SECRETARY types as Milo enters. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat. He's with someone, but  I know he wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary's face is red. The two Lawyers who sat in on his  deposition are with him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we bundled it, the judge is  threatening to enjoin the whole --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm confused, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary has used the phrase before, but the pretense of  ingenuousness is gone; it's witheringly condescending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you tell me they'd be Chapter  12 by the time they could hope to  enjoin? I'm very confused, because  you said they'd be ready to settle.

dialogues.speaker: ANTEROOM
dialogues.text: Milo hears Gary yelling behind the closed door. It's  indecipherable, but we discern an enraged "bullshit!" Mil flips through a copy of Wired, trying to ignore it. The  Lawyers come out, passing swiftly, rather grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on in. (when Milo looks  dubious) He's always happy to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agitated, Gary rather compulsively lines-up the papers, p etc. on his desk; he barely hears the knock at the open  doorframe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- you sent for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still distracted, he finds a page of code on his desk, gi it to Milo. Once again, Milo marvels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really wrote this just today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dark, unsmiling) What're you implying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes are locked. Gary blinks, sags into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything I do is under scrutiny.  The questions they ask, trying to  make anything strategic look sordid. (knits his brow) I'm confused. Doesn't everybody in  business try to get ahead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The purpose of this company isn't to  destroy our competitors any more  than the purpose of living is to  breath. But the software business is  binary: you're a zero or a one. Being  obsessive isn't a crime. It's a  character trait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo just wants to get out. He studies the code to hide h discomfort. Gary watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It scales, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles. For the first time it looks forced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A youthfully upscale place, a converted red-brick warehou Alice looks great. The Waiter pours wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This feels fairly grown up, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo smiles (again it looks forced) raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To our new life. (she's looking at him) ...What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I need to ask you. (when he says nothing) You know you can't keep anything  from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave me some new code-fixes this  morning. I said, "Did you really do  this just today?" Cause I was  impressed. He said "What're you  implying?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just looks at him. He grows a little defensive:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the way he said it. Just the  way my dad did, when he was caught  in a lie. That's how you knew you  were onto something ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just confused) What would it mean, anyway? If he  didn't write it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm asking myself. Does  he have some genius stowed away? Why  not let him write Skywire. (upset) 'Not saying it makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Busboy leaves a basket of rolls. Glum, preoccupied, Mil takes one without looking, brings it to his lips --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Alice, looks at the roll, blanches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the roll back into the basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your boss. He's not your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's nodding) I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't deal with him on that  basis, you better get a new counselor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the very idea hurts) Isn't that -- extreme?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's extreme is what that ER doctor  said when he pumped your stomach.  Eat another sesame seed and that's  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the rolls: covered in seeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, if one little comment from  Gary is gonna upset you this much --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. It's -- a working  relationship. Don't know what I was  expecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles. But his heart's not in it. She hates to see hi suffer. She picks up her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. Let's do the toast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits alone, marking up pages of code as he eats. He  doesn't notice Lisa, standing with her tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you wanna be alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates she should sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just pushed up the schedule on  Skywire apps. How fast are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There is no second place." Plus  every time I get jammed-up, Gary has  an inspiration. (looks at her, curious) Is it like that with your counselor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine's not the CEO. He barely  remembers to take a shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, right. But does he ever just,  like, hand you code?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe once. I re-wrote it, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he smiles) You're compulsive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm-more like -- I have a little  trouble. Trusting people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long story. Not that interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles charmingly to cover whatever she's feeling. Th more enigmatic she is, the more intrigued he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo and Lisa walk, eat ice cream out of paper cups with  Outpost logos. They laugh. We go nearer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, when you were talking about  wishing people were more like  computers. Was that then? Or now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then and now. (when he looks at her) But not right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She maintains eye contact. Her meaning is clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo turns, sees Brian (Stanford classmate, Outpost zealo give an envelope to a Guard at the door of #20; he trots  over to Milo, who is as flustered as another guy might be having been found in bed with a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just dropped off a resume. Almost  got in the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Lisa, back to Milo, wondering why he isn't be introduced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're living here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Thought if I relocated it could  help my case. I'm writing programs  for the local public access station.  Where any whack-job with 100 bucks  gets his own show? God, does it suck. (gives him a business  card) Can you help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing how flushed Milo is, Brian thinks he must have  blundered in on something. He starts to back away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I parked illegally. See y'later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching Brian go) 'Forgot to introduce you. (a beat) I have a girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great. I -- didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station is closed. Milo's car is parked, empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find him, in an illuminated phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been hacking for five night's  straight, I'm really making headway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funky space, posters on the wall, a red Stanford pennan rubber trees at either end of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these, like, White Supremacists  trashed my office, last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wall beyond Teddy the word GOOK (in blood red) has been covered over with paint but still bleeds through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the neighborhood. They  usually hassle Vietnamese grocers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cool. They didn't touch the  machine. Or my disks. Probably didn't  know what they were. So, you a Moonie  yet? (he waits) Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met this girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Come on. Is it serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell Alice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I keep thinking it'll go away.  But there's this -- connection. She's  been hacking since she was little,  she had to move around a lot. Plus I  see her every day, we're working on  the same program. She's -- beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful geek? I don't wanna sound  paranoid, or like a pig, but what're  the chances?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. I guess Larry's got me  totally suspicious of that place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, geeks don't have two  girlfriends. Most don't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't plan this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a window, we watch Milo traverse the quad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd the girl say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There may be a little less trust  after your outburst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary turns back inside, where Phil reads Milo's new code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasn't affected his work, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing does. Still. I want him to  like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is confused by Gary's sincerity; so is Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desi and another Geek watch in astonishment: Gary walks M to his car, his arm circled over Milo's shoulder. He seem to be -- apologizing. EXT./INT. MILO & ALICE'S HOUSE - EVENING Milo comes eagerly up the path: can't wait to tell Alice  what just happened. He enters -- pulls up short. Alice is waiting for him. She's white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know how to say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy was killed last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you -- what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a hate crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo is staggered. She moves to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs onto her, for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establish the funky building, vestiges of police tape on door, a limo and many cars parked out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mixture of Teddy's relatives and Computer Friends have  gathered. In the BG, Teddy's Dad weeps volubly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy's brother, NELSON, shows Milo the workspace: red  Stanford pennant, rubber trees on the desk. Milo, in a su peers at the painted-over epithet on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They trashed his hard disk, all his  back-ups. Nothing's left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They caught the guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson shows Milo a San Jose Mercury: mugshots of two ski headed Aryan Nations Members in their 20's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an airtight case. They found  the weapon with Teddy's blood on it  and their fingerprints. They'd been  arrested twice for beating-up Asians.  How come they weren't in jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo unpins a picture of himself & Teddy from a board

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me about the break-in. He  didn't seem to take it that seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys don't take anything seriously  do you? That's not on a hard drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo is stung by this. Alice appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson? Your mom wants you. It's  time to go to scatter the ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo is pinning the picture back up. The pushpin falls to the floor, he kneels to retrieve it. On the floorboards, sees a thin, shiny plastic filament. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know he was working with  fiber optics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when he looks up, Nelson's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta go too, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he heads out with Alice, he unthinkingly stuffs the  filament in his suit pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A raw beautiful bluff. The sea stretches to infinity behi a smaller group of Mourners. A LAY MINISTER intones the L Prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo approaches Larry with trepidation. Larry nods, it's  okay. They hug each other. They walk slowly back toward t cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you lost all his work. Maybe  I could come down here and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are naive. Look at your employment  contract: you can't work anywhere  else in this field for at least few  years. (he smiles sadly) Not that I don't miss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just thought his work should go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was on the verge of something,  too. He was gonna show us the next  day. He said "The answer's not in  the box, it's in the band." Know  what it means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only meaningful when you've got  40,000 lines of code to back it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, could he write code. Totally  elegant. He had his own style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those really weird, short lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile. For a moment, they've brought Teddy back to l Alice comes up from behind, to fetch Milo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take good care of this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arriving for work, Milo sees Outpost flags at half mast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Milo comes up the hall, Lisa is standing there. We get the feeling she's been waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, perhaps hearing Teddy's words ("what're chances?"). He nods, moves on. She watches him head up th hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo types. There is a rapping on the doorframe. Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were the flags for Teddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary nods. Spontaneously Milo stands, hugs Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had you talked to him much lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just once. 'Guess I was worried we  didn't have anything to talk about,  since work was off-limits. Non- disclosure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about work? Never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant did you find other stuff to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been coming in early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It helps. Alice said it would help.  To focus on something. (a little guilty) 'Don't know what I'd do without her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MILO & ALICE'S HOUSE - MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT Milo sits on the couch, in dim light. Alice comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? (sits by him, holds  him) I miss him, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo eats alone. Through the window, he sees Lisa inside. She's eating alone, too. Gary comes trotting up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is unclasping a manila envelope; he takes pages out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. You must have 20,000 lines of  code there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34,000. But they're real short lines.  'Just came out that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing Gary's code, Milo knits his brow: it must be sort like -- Teddy's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been thinking about the push mechanism  in the handler. And it came over me:  it's in the wrong place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an uncertain smile) The wrong place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answer's not in the box. It's in  the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo's smile freezes. As he stares at Gary, we zoom with reverse dolly so that the background retreats queasily bu Gary remains dominant in frame. For Milo, it feels like t very ground is going out from under him. Gary continues to explain, pointing at lines of code. And Milo pretends to listen. But he can't even make out the w Gary speaks -- he hears only a jumble of echoes. Milo nods mechanically; he wants to scream. Or run. He  perceives, amid the echoes, that Gary is standing, smilin saying "See you later." And he's gone. Milo touches the pages, like some talisman of Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo? You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It strikes him she always shows up at these moments. He  gathers his wits before looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go home. 'Think I ate something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling out of the lot, Milo seizes the car phone. He hit HOME on the speed-dial. Gets a busy signal. Rings off. He about to press re-dial when he sees the Outpost logo bran on the receiver. He throws it down like it's contaminated. EXT. MILO & ALICE'S HOUSE - DAY Middle-of-the-day sounds: chirping birds, school children Milo pulls to the curb at a bad angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fumbles with his keys. When he gets inside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice? Alice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves into the bedroom. He sees her through the window painting in the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands outside the studio. Waits for her to look up. S does. She smiles. Then she sees something's wrong. He wai for her to come out here, where it's safe to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He paces, agitated. She watches him. She's skeptical, but doesn't want to appear unsympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying you think they had  something to do with his death? Nelson  said it was an airtight case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what I'm saying. Maybe --  maybe they hired those guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see Outpost putting its  reputation in the hands of people  like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! I just know it was  Teddy's code. All these ideas flying  in from everywhere. You know how he  says "Any kid working in his garage  can put us out of business?" It's  like they know what every kid's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hack into people's programs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody does work like this on-line.  It's in your PC, or in a mainframe.  Self-contained. They'd have to be,  like, watching people. Physically. (he freezes) Oh Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo's at the closet, rummaging among the clothes hanging there. Alice comes up behind him. He finds his suit jacke He digs in one pocket, then another. He finds the fiber o strand (from Teddy's floor). Shows it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost silently) It's a camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've trooped back outside. She's worried she's indulgi his paranoia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't a broadcast studio. It's --  a surveillance post or something.  That's why they have the dishes on  top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're scaring me. I think we should  just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go where? You can't get away from  people like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Like this?" It's Gary you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it really hurts) You think I don't know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo. Why would he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I know? "Solving a  problem," I guess. Or needing to  control everything. I don't know. (can't think about it) I've gotta get in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if all this were true. There're  20 other buildings. All of them filled  with computers and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only one with dishes on the  roof. The studio's a front. That's  why they keep postponing its opening. (muttered, obsessive) ...gotta get in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, you told me those DOJ Agents  are all over the place. How could  they hope to hide a surveillance  post? (as he mulls this) And how can you get in there, anyway?  With the cameras and the swipe cards --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't just walk away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just walk in, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop the construction work at  six or seven. The parking lot's mostly  clear by two or three in the morning.  Even the early Geeks don't get there  before five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it two? Or is it three? Have you  ever really noticed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows what she's saying: he's unqualified for this, a  space-cadet. She tries to hold him. But he wriggles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I can't just keep my head in the  sand. That's how I got into this  mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He paces, he thinks. She watches him, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how to get in there. But you've  gotta help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared, reluctant) ...Whaddo I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't lie. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing at his window, Milo can see #21. Workers in Hard come out of it, carrying lunchboxes. Milo holds a small  writing pad. He notes the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice parks in front of a drugstore. As she gets out of t car, she looks around uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is at the counter, buying a wind-up alarm clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo watches a car pull out of the parking lot, leaving o one or two others. He writes down the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is at the counter, among children and mothers,  purchasing a chemistry set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches a SECURITY GUARD (DELBERT) go into #21 on his  rounds, notes the time: 3:45 AM. INT. MILO & ALICE'S - STUDIO - NIGHT (CONTINUE MONTAG Alice, wearing dishwashing gloves, ties the alarm clock t small Tupperware container with copper wire. Milo (wearing latex gloves) is at the sink, mixing chemic from the toy chemistry set. Alice approaches with the  container affixed to the clock. As she holds it out Milo  pours the mixture into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER BLACK we hear ticking. The screen lightens to show:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo's alarm clock is set for 11:00. It sits amid mops an cleaning products.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo stands in the open door of a refrigerator, as if  searching for a soda. He's looking up the hall, waiting f someone. He consults his watch. 10:53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes a GUARD; he nods to Milo as he passes. The Gua opens a door with his card. Milo rushes through the door the Guard's swipe -- "tailgating."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you gotta use your own -- (noticing) Where's your ID?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo cops an attitude. He's not completely convincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my job, I gotta --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's getting better) The kind of stock options I'm sitting  on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Shrot, the ex-cop in charge of physical security, loo up as the Guard escorts Milo into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bomb explodes. The blast is tiny but loud (glass clea bottles ring; plastic bottles moan).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits, watches Shrot encode a new card for him, findi his info on a terminal. On a monitor behind Shrot, Milo s Programmers being ushered out of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every geek has to try this once to  show me how smart he is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER GUARD rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was an explosion in a Y-sector  closet, we're evacuating the whole  sector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot comes to his feet, grabs a holster (with gun) off a shelf. Milo, looking flummoxed, stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un-nh, can't wander around without  ID now. Just park your ass in that  chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits. Shrot goes out with the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whole place reeks of fuckin' ammonia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo moves quickly to the wall, reads a chart with the Gu Schedule, runs his finger down it til he finds the name o the Guard on the 3 AM shift: DELBERT, KEN.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: Guards open closet doors, shine their flashlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo has moved to Shrot's seat. He's encoding a fresh car with Ken Delbert's information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panning off the civil defense sign we find Shrot standing a closet, examining a piece of the alarm clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo is at work, bringing up schematic screens, diagnosin the system with his unique concentration. Panning to the window, we see the evacuated Programmers  enjoying themselves on the lawn. It's a rare, exciting ev they jump around, miming explosions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot and the Guard collect pieces of the bomb out of the debris, puts them in a tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo brings up the screen that controls the #21 cameras. the monitors, he sees nothing very interesting: a hallway room under construction... He pulls down a menu. RECORDING is highlighted. He clicks PLAYBACK. The image hardly changes, but a Guard wanders  through. He types, the tape rewinds (the Guard moves  backwards). He finds a neutral spot (showing an empty  hallway), stops the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary, Randy & Phil approach Shrot; Gary stares at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. Glorified cherry bomb.  Right by the civil defense sign?  Some geek's idea of irony. I been  saying we need a camera in this hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing in this hall.  Someone's pulling your chain, as  usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking aloud) Unless it's a diversion. Milo's in  my office. He was tailgating, so I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary explodes, with incredulity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo? Try to have a clue. Try to  think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary strides off. Shrot feels unfairly maligned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kid's the great white hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could get it out of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy and Phil head up the hall. Shrot watches them. Even his "intellectual superiors" are convinced of Milo's  innocence, he isn't. He walks swiftly back toward his office. Then he runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo reads a warning message. DOWNLOADING PLAYBACK STREAM
