dialogues.speaker: RECORD CYCLE WILL CAUSE BIT OVERLOAD. DO YOU WISH TO PROC
dialogues.text: Y/N. He types Y. The glitch freezes the tape (we see it lock into place): shows the empty hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've let the Programmers back in. They head up the hal as Shrot heads down it. He pushes past them gruffly. He knows he's enhancing his Neanderthal image (they make  cracks) but he's more interested in obeying his instinct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo immobilizes another camera in #21... and another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot rounds the corner. His office is in view, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, at the keyboard, closes up windows, one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot is back, he has only to round the corner to see Mil We assume his POV as he does so: Milo sits in the chair where Shrot left him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pan off the clock (3:20 AM) to find Milo at his desk, loo at the clock with a certain dread. It's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo walks the path between the two buildings, fiddling  nervously with the dummied swipe card. Hearing footfalls behind him, he whirls: it's a Geek lopi to his car. He smiles. Milo smiles: waits, walks on. Nearing #21, Milo looks around, making sure no one else i around. His POV (panning): A Programmer works late, visib through a lighted window in #20... The dog sculpture with cocked ears sits atop the Day Care, its quizzical express seeming to wonder what Milo is up to... The Geek he just racing by on foot now pulls out of the parking lot in his James Bond BMW... Milo arrives at the entrance. Heart pounding, he brings t card to the slot. Will he trigger that awful alarm? He slides the card, the door clicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters: concrete floor, unpainted walls, construction  lights. At the inner door he looks up at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: A MONITOR
dialogues.text: that shows us where Milo stands, minus Milo. Widen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUARD packs up his stuff, getting ready to go home. The new guard, KEN DELBERT enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking out his cup) Big night. Switched from tea to  coffee. Brought new meaning to my  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Maybe I'll start my rounds  with #21 tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a wild man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo moves up a hall with unpainted walls, bare floors,  unconnected wires. The only illumination is from construc lights on the concrete floor. Opening doors, he sees: Bare rooms. Wall plates ready to receive electrical equip bundles of wire hanging out. In other words: the building as advertised, so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delbert comes out with his flashlight, heads across the c swept path that leads to #21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo nears a set of double-doors at the end of the hall. hears a low ominous hum from within. Convinced he's found something, he quickens his pace. He's about to swipe his  card when a beam of light bounces along the wall. He presses himself into an alcove. Through a chink in the unfinished wall he sees: Delbert come in the front door. His rounds consist of shi his torch up at the cameras, making sure the red lights a on. He walks right past Milo (who doesn't breath). Delbert swipes open the double doors, leans in: the hummi gets louder. ON MILO: pressing himself into the alcove. Delbert turns around, heads back down the hall... exits t building. Milo waits a beat before heading to the end of the hall.  Using the card, he enters

dialogues.speaker: A BIG SPACE
dialogues.text: A studio-to-be, architectural touches like soffits framed but not plaster-boarded. The portentous hum comes from ar a corner. He approaches, convinced the answer lies here.  Clearing the wall he sees: A squat emergency generator sitting on the floor, powerin construction lights. Something you'd buy at Sears.

dialogues.speaker: EXT.
dialogues.text: Through infra-red binoculars we see Milo come out, lookin left and right, to make sure he hasn't been observed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Now he knows: nothin' in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy turns back into the room, where Phil is sifting thr papers spread over a coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he'll get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of which...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy pulls the blinds shut, joins Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a high angle, we track Milo, as he walks along the p to a bench. The camera passes briefly behind a dark objec in the foreground (dog sculpture) as we track him.

dialogues.speaker: QUAD
dialogues.text: Milo sags onto the bench. He stares out, perplexed, suffe Then he knits his brow. He seems to be studying -- the gr Or rather the shadow stretched out in front of him: the  looming silhouette of the dog atop the Day Care. He stands up, turns around. REVERSE ON: The whimsical canine. Push toward it's ears cocked to the sky... Then toward a single ear, framed by fur-brown conc but with a smooth, concave inner surface of enamelled met satellite dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) ...in a tree...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the entrance, Milo applies the swipe-card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps in on colorful carpeting, amid balls & tricy Kid's artwork hangs on the wall. He moves through this ro into the

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER ROOM
dialogues.text: 20 screens glow. They hang suspended over a wide, ringed  table, a chair at each keyboard. Indeed, Gary has spared expense for the toddlers: they're flat, sleek, digital  screens. At the moment, they show colorful, childish cont drawings that say WHERE I WANNA WORK (e.g.: a spaceship). There are a dozen more screens on tables at the perimeter the room showing screensavers (eg: angelfish swimming). Milo moves slowly around the table, studying the screens. Not surprisingly, most of the WHERE I WANNA WORK drawings are of desks or tables with computers. Tracking just ahead of Milo, we get to a screen that show workstation with a red pennant on the wall, a rubber plan at each end of a desk. Even in contour form it's -- famil Milo passes it. And comes back to it. Staring at it, he sits. He begins typing. [The drawing st occupies the screen, but in a window he's brought up at t bottom, there is dense, DOS-looking code.] He types furio numbers, symbols, backslashes. Whatever he's trying to do a challenge even to him. He deletes lines, begins anew, h frustration evident. As he works through the layers of code, the pixels on the screen start to fill in. The contour lines slowly dissolv into a live broadcast image of Teddy's workstation in  Sunnyvale (eerily empty, now). When all the pixels have fallen into place, Milo hears CL CLICK CLICK CLICK CLICK from every direction, as all the  screens in the room fill in with live broadcast images. A of them show variations on a theme: A workstation seen by a camera over-the-shoulder of a  programmer (if he were present). The stations are of vari shapes and sizes, but in each case we have an unobstructe view of screen & keyboard. At this hour, few programm present. One guy has fallen asleep, his head on a desk. A Japanese Geek is hard at work: it's day there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Randy work at the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you download Corey? In San Jose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. 'Have to go back over there. (he stands, stretches) Be so much easier if we could walk  in the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look anything like a three- year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo works the keyboard. Again, the code gets dense and  obscure as he goes deeper. He succeeds in calling-up a  graphical interface. Among the menus he can choose from a TARGET SCHOOLS, PD UPLOADS, RX UPLOADS. He clicks Target Schools, a menu shoots down (Berkeley, C Tech, etc.). He clicks Stanford, then Chin, Teddy. Two wi open. In one, there is a video stream of Teddy winning an award in the Gate's Bldg. In the other, uploaded police v stenciled SUNNYVALE PD) of the White Supremacists whose m shots we saw in the San Jose Mercury; they're being  interrogated. In the first window, Teddy's image dissolves into a handh crime-scene video (marked SV-PD) of a ransacked grocery s "DIE GOOK!" is painted on a wall. Milo looks confused: so "narrative" is unfolding, but it remains obscure without  audio. He types some more. In the bottom window, he brings up convoluted text regard the audio. About the only phrases we can understand are:  "Audio Block ON" and "Hardware Requirement: Magnetic Filt Type PBX-R17." His eyes cast about the room for some suitable hardware  substitute. He digs in his shirt pocket. He takes out his swipe card, studies it. He casts about some more, till he sees some kids' safety scissors in a jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy whistles as he heads up the hall. Arriving at the d with the Civil Defense sticker, he swipes his card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On-screen, long-lens footage shows a low building; the Ar Nations suspects come out of it. A still photo appears in the 2nd window: a steel hasp. Milo's eyes are narrowed: what am I seeing? Meantime, he reaching under the table where he has removed a plate fro the mainframe terminal, exposing hardware within. He has trimmed the swipe card to size and is wedging its  magnetic strip into a metal slot. He wiggles the card. We hear an eerie fibrillation, which flattens into the voice a serene, eminently sane female:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- run this methamphetamine lab known  to Federal Authorities, per ND 47,  from which we removed the implement,  fingerprints intact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crime-scene video streams in now stenciled FBI by the  time/date). A handheld camera pans a blood-spattered wall then shows a mutilated Asian murder victim. (All of this  footage is made even eerier by the jerky glitches always  present in streaming video, and its sinister graininess.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI footage, procured by ND 47, shows  the aftermath of an Aryan Nations'  killing in Denver. Note the evidence  of torture, which is typical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo pales as he realizes he is watching a primer on how  racial killings are done. He hears a creaking noise behind him, and whirls. It's the classroom hamster, on his wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still whistling, Randy descends some metal stairs, enters vast bomb shelter (canned foods, etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo has tapped into his own file: footage of him lecturi at Stanford (as an RA), pointing to a whiteboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- complete immersion in code-writing  renders him both unobservant and  suggestible [click]. On two occasions  he went truant from classes to attend  Comix Conventions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audio crackles and drops out again. Milo's eyes narro he sees video of Alice, sitting on a folding chair, speak to someone. She has a harder look, pulls on a Marlboro. What's he seeing? He wiggles the jerry-rigged hardware al urgently, till the narration crackles back on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Rebecca P, a Connecticut art stu-  dent facing Federal drug charges,  whose records were supplied to us by  N.D. 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears her voice under the Narration, answering an unse Interrogator (sounds like Phil). It's a job interview. Mi subtly, unconsciously shakes his head, as if to deny what his eyes see. The narration begins to fibrillate, again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armed with his personal files, she  was easily able to ingratiate herself  with the socially maladroit Milo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audio drops out as Milo sees uploaded medical files a ER photos of himself marked STANFORD MEDICAL CENTER: he's waxen, bloated, gasping for breath. With a certain dread, Milo jams the card in deeper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...she planted the sesame seed both  to test the extent of his proclivity  and to provide a bonding experience,  since she would quote "save his life."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo is devastated, disbelieving. Now he sees real-time E footage: an Allergy Victim, bloated, twitching, gasping,  dying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- should it be needed Milo's allergy  is the ideal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audio crackles out. But Milo doesn't have the heart t bring it back: he can fill in the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy traverses a well-lit tunnel. Still whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numb now, Milo clicks randomly: crime footage, personal  records, animations -- it all flies by with Chuck Worman- like speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note that the cult members are found  reclining after swallowing the [click]  Syringe marks best hidden at base of  scrotum [click] mimics high blood  alcohol [click] indistinguishable  from kidney failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo closes his eyes, leans back: overwhelmed. Suddenly h sits forward, whispers almost fervently as he types:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't be one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves slowly through stacks of pre-school supplies toward a windowed door at the back of the room. RANDY appears in the window, lit ominously from below. He applies his swipe card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo watches footage of Lisa taken by surveillance cam- e she is outside #21, trying to peek in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...needs to be watched, due to her  heightened level of suspicion --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one window, footage of Lisa casing the hallway before  going into Milo's office; in another, footage of her eati lunch with Milo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and to her possible contagion of  key employees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo clicks. A MAN's pair of mug shots appear. In the oth window, a grade-school yearbook photo of Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In August '86 Lisa informed her mother  of the sexual molestation by her  stepfather, and of his threat to  kill her should she tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo watches streaming local news footage of a man being  taken from a courtroom in shackles (jerky, grainy). He's  lost the audio, but doesn't need it, anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy climbs up to the main floor... whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo watches eerie crime-scene footage: a Girl with her t slashed. But then, hearing nearly-distant whistling, he clicks on  windows furiously: closing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy rounds a corner. He enters the

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER ROOM
dialogues.text: The screens show the children's contour images, again. Wh Milo? Randy takes a seat at the same console Milo was at, and b to type. Camera booms slowly down beneath table-level to  find: MILO hanging onto the underside of the table, knuckles wh as he clings to metal table braces. The toes of his sneak are jammed into the space between a black plastic data to and the table bottom. Randy shifts in his seat, his knee rising toward Milo's b Milo arches it, avoids a knee by mere millimeters. RANDY: brings up a shot of a Programmer at work, zooms in his screen to begin collecting his code. MILO: begins to lose his grip as sweat forms on his brow  and, worse, on his hands. They're giving way. RANDY: clicks. A printer across the room start making a h copy of the purloined code. MILO: stares in horror as the data tower his toes are jam on top of starts to shift -- threatening to disengage fro its ports. He tries to lift it back up with heels of his  shoes. RANDY: knits his brow as his screen flickers. He keeps ty but starts to lower his head: he's going to look under th table. MILO: winces as he presses the tower upward with his heel while trying to maintain his balance... RANDY: lowering his head, keeps his eyes on the screen, h keys. Just as he is about to clear the level of the table the screen re-illumines. He comes back up. MILO: having extended his legs to support the tower, feel his hands slipping... RANDY: closes up the window... MILO: flops to the carpet(!) just as -- RANDY pushes away from the table... From the floor MILO watches him walk over to the printer, collect his  hardcopy, and disappear from view. Milo listens: the door clicks shut, the whistling recedes

dialogues.speaker: BACK ROOM
dialogues.text: Milo traces Randy's steps. He sees the door with the Civi Defense sticker, intuits how Randy got here, i.e, how one moves, unobserved, between the Day Care and #20. He sags against the wall. Wondering what to do, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits in his idling car, staring at his own house, up the street. How can he go in there? He puts the car in gear, does a U-Turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Deux Chevaux is parked on the street outside a govern building. Not many people are around, yet. A Janitor hose down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo slides a business card across a reception desk. It's the one the rumpled Prosecutor, Lyle Barton, gave him tha day in Palo Alto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave me this. 'Said I should come  see him if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I wait in his office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's locked, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over his shoulder, then back again, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait in his outer office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits on a wooden bench, foot tapping. Hearing Barton voice, he comes to his feet. Barton enters with a Co-Work holding a container of coffee, discussing the particulars a case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I make the call, or do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo is relieved the second he sees Barton's kindly face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barton, do you remember me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's -- Milo, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I need to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me two seconds with Lacy here? (unlocks his door) Go on in, I won't be a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo enters as Barton finishes up with his colleague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make the call, but I think you  need to send a Fax first (etc.).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo paces. He surveys framed diplomas, commendations and photos on the wall. He takes comfort in their solidity:  pictures of Barton's teenage Kids, Barton and Wife at the Grand Canyon. There's a college football photo, a young B with his team. Milo studies it, smiles. Move in on the ph till we see the number on Barton's Notre Dame football je ND 47. Milo's smile fades. It takes a moment before he even hear Barton behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hi. Thank you for seeing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Milo takes the seat in front of the desk (mind spinnin Barton moves to his own chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What seems to be the problem? You  look a little upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. I am, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he gonna say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend, my best friend, Teddy,  was killed in Silicon Valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was racially motivated. He's  Chinese. He was. And... I know  sometimes the FBI gets involved with  that. Don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's a Civil Rights violation.  But generally we let the local police  and DA do their work first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- just wanna help bring these  guys to justice. They're neo-Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me look into it, see what's being  done. Frankly, it's not my area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he gets up) 'Just didn't know who else to talk  to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (circles an arm over  Milo) And Outpost? You're happy there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MILO & ALICE'S HOUSE - MORNING Alice is on the phone in the front room. Agitated, she pu on a pencil (surrogate cigarette). We hear Phil through t receiver:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Didn't mention he was going to the  Justice Department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like him, is it? To do a thing  like that without telling you. You're  not losing your hold on him, are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll tell me when he gets home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be a test, won't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead of busting my chops you should  do something about that girl. Fire  her. Or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa's an extremely valuable member  of the Skywire team. We've got our  eyes on her. You keep yours on Milo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she hangs up) Prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. MILO & ALICE'S HOUSE - MORNING Milo comes up the path. He pauses as he nears the door: h not sure he can pull this off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Milo enters, Alice rushes to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost nine, I've been so  worried! (she takes his hands) What did you see in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches him as he collapses onto the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what they said it is. An  unfinished broadcast studio. You  were right... I just drove to Seattle  and back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember Lyle Barton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Justice Department guy who came  to the apartment when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After I broke into 21 -- which was  insane, thank God they didn't catch  me! -- I just drove around. Trying  to figure out what possessed me. You  know what? I've been putting my own  guilt on Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guilt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) If I'd stayed down there, maybe this  wouldn't've happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor baby. You know that's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits by him, touches her hand to his face tenderly. H closes his eyes for a moment, steels himself to her touch Then he forces himself to cup his hand over hers. But he can't stand it. He gets up, looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought, instead of indulging all  these paranoid delusions, risking my  job, alienating Gary, scaring you, I  should do something useful with my  grief. Help them find Teddy's killers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't see her smile: is that all. Assuming an  appropriately concerned expression, she moves toward him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns him around, kisses him. Her eyes are closed. Hi remain open. He's looking at her. Trying to comprehend th treachery. She touches him, breathes heavily. She wants more than ki to prove to herself how wrong Phil was, her professional  pride insulted. Or perhaps it's more personal than that,  especially with Lisa as a potential rival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through their kisses) ...been such a long night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she doesn't stop. She moans as she presses herself to him: wants proof of his devotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on top of her in the moment just after. Her eyes are closed. He stares at her -- glares at her -- with what we recognize as spent anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was -- different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. She knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't feel it? So intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's clear is, she liked it. A clap of thunder takes us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pouring. Milo stands outside, wearing a slicker, loo in the window at someone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PIZZA PLACE
dialogues.text: Lisa reads a paperback at a table, a slice of pizza on he plate, an umbrella hooked to her chair. Sensing someone  standing over her, she looks up. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're not avoiding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits across from her. He doesn't know where to start

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around, wants to make sure no one's listening. H speaks very quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I snuck into #21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you do a thing like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought about it too. You've  been suspicious for a while. But  it's not happening in there. It's  happening in the Day Care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Day Care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Men with even features enter the restaurant. One has laptop case slung over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we go someplace else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in a bandshell. The rain falls heavily, drips off the eaves. She holds the filament from Teddy's workspace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy to know who the smart geeks  are, the schools tell 'em. They upload  medical files, school records,  pharmacy files. They'd be happy just  to steal code forever. But when a  program gets close to fruition. Like  Teddy. He was almost there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why would they --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know. There is no second place.  And what's the risk? The killings're   undetectable, they're hand-tailored,  they make "sense." I mean, they're  in the information business. They  have scenarios for all of us, too.  In case we find out too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's peering at him. He reads her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not one of them. Not trying to  "suss you out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed my best friend! I'm living  with somebody they pay to go to bed  with me. Can't you trust somebody  just once? I don't wanna be alone  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His plea is so ardent, his humanity so transparent. But s can't quite do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Milo... I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles sadly as she backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forcefully) I know why you're so secretive. Why  you won't let anybody near you. (quieter) I know what he did to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to sound tough; there are tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's in my -- file?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to comfort her. He takes a step toward her. She  shakes her head: no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that my -- scenario? (when he hesitates) Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd frame him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified) He's out of prison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he nods) They're already watching you. If  they had to, they'd give him this  drug that mimics an alcoholic  blackout. He'd wake up not even  remembering his "act of revenge."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She draws her hands to her face as the facade cracks. She weeps silently. He moves to her, carefully, slowly, seein her fear, her trauma. He touches her shoulders. She tense tries to back away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he holds on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's gonna hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, he wraps his arms around her. She remains tense for a moment, then yields, pressing her face into his shoulder. The rain drums on the bandshell.  After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always felt if a -- boy I liked  ever found out -- he'd run. He'd  think I was unclean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She clings to him tightly, now, the wall of her mistrust  breached after all the years of pain, secrecy, shame. A wide shot: they hold each other, alone in the storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All his suspicions were allayed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice nods. She sits in front of leather-bound books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at Gary's house. On the hot seat. Phil and Randy wa her. Gary does, too, but deep in shadow, behind a desk, a remove. Rain falls heavily on the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said it made sense that Gary's  code was like Teddy's, that that  clichГ© about great minds was true.  Said it was all about his own guilt. (she shrugs) Plus, he has a tendency to get Gary  mixed-up with his dad once in a while.  It always passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't acting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he knows how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks convinced. Gary doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the highway (cars with morning commuters whiz by) we see Milo pumping gas at a self-serve; Lisa fills-u in the next lane. Ostensibly, they have run into each oth on the way to work. They are smiling, casual. Only when we cut close do we see that their expressions b no connection to their words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got this guy in the DOJ,  maybe others. We tell the wrong  person, it's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can we trust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's always a logical answer --  you just have to define the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She defines it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you let go of a secret without  telling the wrong person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pretends to need help lifting her car hood: "a helple female." He comes over to help her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't tell anybody. (she's puzzled) We tell everybody. At once. So there's  no secret left to protect. When  everybody knows, they don't dare  touch us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Shrot is on the phone. Behind him, a nerdy security  programmer, LEN DIETZ, is at the console that controls th security cameras (the ones Milo futzed with).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) No, Tony can't fill in for you, he's  not at your authorization level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrolling, Len knits his brow: he's found something odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob? You better look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo checks Lisa's oil for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we post it on the Net?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There're so many disinformation sites  about Gary already. Where he has  devil's horns or they crop him in  with Saddam Hussein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot stands over Len's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could it be a glitch? Something the  construction workers caused?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlikely. All 14 cameras are frozen.  Do we call Randy and Phil? Tell 'em  there may have been a break-in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. 'Love to bust my ass cause  I'm not in frigging Mensa. (walks to the window) I swear to God, it's that kid Milo,  I told 'em so in the first place,  but they didn't even wanna hear about  it. (turns to Len) Let's run a printout on card entries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo shows Lisa the oil stick. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mainstream media. TV, or a  newsmagazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. But Gary's tied-in to a lot  of media conglomerates. Have to be  careful who we pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could cross-reference a data base  on media ownership. But not on our  own computers. Not even at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not at my happy home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot and Len watch a laser printer, as it spits out line after line after line of swipe card entries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LASER PRINTER spits out code. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo watches new Skywire code emerge from his printer. Gary is in the doorway behind him: watching Milo, scrutin izing him. Sensing someone, Milo turns and looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary, hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look a little tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay. It's going well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Have a look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary takes the page. As he reads it over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you move around so much?  When you were a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My dad was a compulsive gambler.  Only he didn't think he was. That  applied to guys who didn't have a  "system." "Losers," who played games  of chance. He could "read" people,  so chance had nothing to do with it.  No matter how deep a hole he dug  himself, he'd give you the whole  speech. And you'd better not point  out the obvious. (he shrugs) His creditors would catch up to him.  Loan sharks or whatever. He'd wake  us in the middle of the night. Off  we'd go, again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you tell the kids? At  your new school? You had to come up  with a good story, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo thinks: he's testing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just went deeper into the  machine. Preferred being the geek to  having to explain. Lying would've  been worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Worse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause he was a liar. And I hated  him. (mimicking a voice) "Get your head out of that machine,  wise up to the real world." The more  he mocked me the deeper I went. Cause  if being savvy meant being like him -- (he shrugs) Guess that's why I'm kind of clueless,  even now. Didn't cultivate my  conniving side. 'Not sure I even  have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so hard on yourself. With a  brain like yours, you could connive  with the best of 'em I bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary smiles. There's no way to read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establish the humble building, in a Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa and Milo sit together in front of a monitor. A Kid d his homework on a computer at the next table. Milo shakes his head, as he scrolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's buying up pretty much everything:  cable companies, baby bells, picture  libraries, museum rights, film  archives... Getting ready for Skywire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she's thinking) What about "60 Minutes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they dig stuff like this. (he types, then reads) "CBS News has partnered with Outpost  Information Systems in a cable news  network due to launch Fall of 2001."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But still, you can't say CBS wouldn't  love to break something like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's shaking his  head) Say there's just one "mole" working  there, like Barton at the DOJ. How  do we know he's not the guy we've  contacted? Or she? Or the guy she  works for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the next table, she notices a Lady reading Time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (types, reads) Time-Warner has a 40 per cent stake  in Gary's set-top device. That also  takes out CNN. (scrolling & scrolling) "GE joins Outpost in new venture,"  which means NBC is out. "Disney joins  Outpost," ABC is out. "Outpost and  Newscorp in new deal," Fox is out.  Any of these places could have a  mole. Or all of 'em. (still scrolling) It's like a a continuous loop. We  can go to some alternative press  place that 1,000 people read, get  them and us killed. But anything big  enough for this is a parent of or a  subsidiary to something Gary's got a  finger in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's thought of something. He's watching the nerdy Kid,  smiling sadly, perhaps identifying with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How close are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got 12 satellites up. He's got  dishes on top of 21. He's building  this -- (gestures at the screen) mega-network for Skywire. Let's use  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move in on Milo as he thinks it over with a mixture of  excitement and skepticism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo and Lisa walk in the park outside the library, think it through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't just assume they're standing  by to receive Skywire 12 months from  launch. I'd have to write in an aglet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's how on-line services push logos  they wanna sell you. You don't ask  for 'em, they just appear. 'Have to  work on it somewhere besides my office  or my house. And then the quality of  the broadcast wouldn't exactly be  digital, that's 12 months away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they'd still get the idea, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have to design a graphic  interface to make the data pop. Maybe  some audio, too. To tie it all in to  Gary. How long would that take you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a standard GUI. Once I've got a  concept, it's maybe three day's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary knows I'm close on Skywire. We  have to do this fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before they kill somebody else, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a new wrinkle) Oh, man. I'd have to get into Gary's  house. To get the satellite positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean -- break in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what if the broadcast dishes on  top of 21 aren't hot yet? You said  the place isn't finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The complications pile up. They walk. They think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go look. (when he looks dubious) They'll just have a few more pictures  of me snooping around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to a fountain and balustrade at the edge of the park, stop walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her) Why were you so careless?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the worst they would do is  fire me. Who knew they took  termination so literally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallows humor. What a game girl. He's nuts about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you snooping in my office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (she gets bashful) I liked you. I was checking you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her. There are no constraints now, there's no  "adulterous" guilt: they kiss with a passion deferred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow push-in on the phone on Milo's desk: it's ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is calling him. Her face hardens, she hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we pan the Best Western decor (in semi-darkness):

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Think everybody in this place is  here the same reason we are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause their apartments might be  bugged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo grins. He & Lisa lie in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told Teddy about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A beautiful geek? What're the  chances?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, rather bashfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt guilty. 'Cause I "owed so  much" to Alice. But even then I was  starting to wonder. Is it so great  to be so consumed by this one thing  that you let another person do your  thinking for you? If you have a  lucrative skill, it's all anybody  wants from you. You grow older but  you don't grow up. You turn into --  into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's painful for him: losing a second father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry used to say how the guys who  wrote the first cool operating  systems, like the UNIX guys at  Berkeley? They just gave it away.  They figured it was human knowledge,  it belonged to the world, like  Shakespeare or aspirin. 'Know what  I'm gonna do after we broadcast the  incriminating stuff? Air the Skywire  code. Then nobody can have a monopoly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. ALICE & MILO'S HOUSE - LATER Alice is in bed. In the darkness, Milo comes in as quietl as possible. But she switches on the bedside lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you? (holding his gaze) You know you can't keep anything  from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, yeah. I did something naughty...  There's this amazing Comix store in  Seattle. (is she buying it?) To tell you the truth, I did it once  or twice at Stanford. 'Guess I can't  keep anything from you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she buys it: it's in the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she smiles) I won't turn you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot and Len go over the print-out of the card entries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every entry was authorized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're we looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any irregularity in the pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MILO & ALICE'S HOUSE - MORNING Morning TV is on in the kitchen. A Seattle station airs a puff piece about a party at Gary's house: people in forma clothes (including Gary & his Wife) hold drinks and e canapГ©s on the terrace over Lake Washington. (Gary's hai is different: it's file footage.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last years' party-goers pledged over  $2 million to the Museum; this year's  event promises to raise even more.  Lured in part by the chance to see  the stunning Boyd house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice, grinding coffee, isn't paying attention. Milo is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't he ask us to his party.  He's never even met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has thousands of employees, Milo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for the Museum. He knows you're  a painter. If anybody should be  invited --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you think I'm too attached to  him, but still. I am close to Gary.  And you're the most meaningful person  in my life. (he gets up) I'm going back to the Comix place,  why should I be killing myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's out the door. She's not entirely displeased by s a dramatic demonstration of his loyalty to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a satellite dish. We pan from the base of the di to the wiring: a cable is fused to a component box. Lisa is on the scaffolding, having climbed it brazenly, i broad daylight. She holds a small metal box with a meter two clamps. She applies the clamps to the base of the cab The needle on the meter dances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Get down here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was expecting to be busted. Still, she's scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Catholic school on a wooded lane. Schoolgirls in unifor play on the swings and hopscotch courts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo types madly on a four-year-old PC. It takes him a mo to notice SISTER BEATRICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a lifesaver. My PC crashed  just before finals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of us knows how to use it. I'm  thinking of taking a course. (she wants to look) May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her, we see the complex lines of code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa sits with Bob Shrot. She's unfolding a page of sketc paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed t'see it up close for a  graphic. The outpost with a dish on  top? I climbed up there to get it  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him an unfinished rendering of the dish. He loo at her, at the drawing, at her again. She's scared, but t to hide it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands back the drawing) Next time you ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relieved, she gets up. The meter tumbles to the floor, th She goes white. But when she looks up, she sees Shrot didn't see it: Len is standing in the inner door, w a printout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Might of found something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa grabs up the meter as Shrot joins Len. As she goes o she hears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delbert seems to enter #21 twice.  Without leaving the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get him in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo looks up as his train comes into a station. Lisa ent the car, carrying a stack of comix. He stands, they kiss, takes the comix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I knocked off the aglet, as  soon as I get a passable version of  Skywire we're there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dishes are juiced up, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo? Shrot suspects somebody broke  into #21. I was in his office when  he was reviewing the card readouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) They know I broke in. Alice helped  me. (figuring it out) Shrot's not one of them. He's  blundering into this on his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know about the Day Care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly anybody does, that's the beauty  part. No cameras, the DOJ doesn't  bother with it, it's accessed by a  tunnel they boast about. You know  the best place to hide a leaf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's old, in a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo? What if Shrot notices somebody  entered the Day Care at four A.M.?  And tells them about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other: the consequences of this discove would be deadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A busy lunch hour. Milo is eating with some other Program including Desi. There's a stir of excitement in the room. Gary comes straight to Milo's table; all conversation  instantly drops out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo stands. Gary hands him a heavy vellum invitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving a benefit for the art  museum Thursday night. Thought you'd  like to bring Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody at the table is listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great! Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he goes) 'Sorry about the late notice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits down. Everybody's looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sorry about the late notice?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delbert is seated across from Shrot and Len. Shrot holds printout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you enter #21 twice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot hands Delbert the printout. Delbert looks at it: de with coded entries. He stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This thing's screwed-up. Look here. (shows it to them) 'Shows me going into the Day Care  that night. I never been in the Day  Care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot narrows his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sits with Lisa as she brings up the graphic interfac she's designed for the Skywire broadcast. It's an Outpost desktop, with recognizable logos, fonts, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One window'll be obits I downloaded,  based on the scenarios you described.  The other windows'll accommodate the  surveillance stuff you told me about.  The idea is, this works with anything,  since we can't edit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods. [It's not necessary for us to understand what sh saying, just so Milo does.] She holds up an audio copy of Gary's book, The Next Highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same with the excerpts I'm choosing:  they'll play against any of the images  you described.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. (something preys on  his mind) How am I gonna get away from the  party long enough to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could always say you have to go  the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's lame, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll come up with something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He already looks nervous. We begin to hear live music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music echoes from inside. Push past a line of cars an limousines in the lit-up drive, Milo's car at the head of it. Milo and Alice get out. As they go inside, she pulls a ta from the sleeve of his just-bought dinner jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Milo and Alice enter, he sees a Balthus painting re- digitize to a Mondrian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They called the house to ask who's  your favorite painter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice smiles, Milo forces a smile: it'll be even harder t sneak away, now. They pass a doorway where a Houseman stands, to keep gues from entering residential rooms (the ones Milo must pass  through to get to Gary's workroom). A Guy in a pretentiou hip tux tries to peek in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Sir, this part of the residence  is restricted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo looks a little more tense...

dialogues.speaker: PARTY ROOM
dialogues.text: The room is full of people. A long windowed wall has been opened onto a lakeside terrace, where more Guests drink a chat, and an orchestra plays. A giant Mondrian digitizes on the wall: the world's large ID card. Milo sinks a little more. Across the room, Gary, his Wife (a blandly pretty blond) two Men are grouped around a Monet set on an antique ease (thus clearly the real thing; Mrs. Boyd has prevailed.) G notices the giant digital Mondrian. MILO takes two flutes of champagnes off a tray. He hands to Alice as Gary et. al. approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice, I'm Gary. This is my wife,  Clarissa. (handshakes, etc.) Milo, this is Barry Linder, who's  visiting from Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINDER is a short, tan man of 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate being the Hollywood guy. It's  so limiting. Meet my friend, Ricky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICKY is 25-years-old; he looks like a Polo model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barry's studio's gonna help fill the  Skywire pipeline, thought you guys  should meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his mind elsewhere) Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE: the orchestra, playing. ANGLE: a group of SOCIETY TYPES chatting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a sweetheart. He gave 10,000  PC's to the Library Association.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All 10,000 of which will be signed  onto his browser, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait'll all the books are on-line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE: Milo, Alice, Gary, Barry Linder, Clarissa, Ricky.  Milo looks utterly preoccupied...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The merchandising implications are  epic. A kid's watching the movie, he  points and clicks at the laser blaster --  before the reel's even over he's  ordered the toy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I mean -- Devil's Advocate --  won't that influence the content?  Won't the artists complain? The  directors or writers or whoever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Artists? Darling, the only art left  in America is business. You're in  Picasso's house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary smiles as everyone toasts him, except Milo; he hasn' heard any of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The irreverence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. TRACK MILO as he wends his way through laughing, chatting Guests, dread and determination on his face. He moves awa from us, enters the

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE HALL
dialogues.text: speaks to the Houseman who guards the residential rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to use one over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates an area on Milo's side of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's like eight women waiting in  line. They take forever. (winces: painful  bladder) Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a door immediately behind him. As the Housem watches, Milo goes into the

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: He stands there a moment, breathes deeply. He cracks open the door. The Houseman is turning away another Guest; Mil makes his move.

dialogues.speaker: DEN-LIKE ROOM
dialogues.text: Looking over his shoulder, Milo hurries to a door at the end of the room, silently cursing the Mondrian that inevi appears. The Houseman looks over his shoulder, sees the closed bat door, assumes Milo's still inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary chats with his guests. Alice looks up at the digital art, now a Bosch again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo walks fast. As he passes from one room to next, he s a Mondrian: he's been in this room. All the austere,  tastefully decorated rooms are blending together. He stands in the center of the room making quarter turns. Through each of four (open) doorways he sees a perfectly- appointed "den," the ultimate expression of bland, rich,  professionally-decorated taste. He's lost. He starts into one room -- backs up -- goes into another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Houseman looks over his shoulder again. He sees the  Mondrian and, in the room beyond that, another Mondrian. He moves to the bathroom door, knocks on it. Opens it. He pulls a sleek walkie-talkie from his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, still lost, is getting frantic. He doubles back, cu toward another wing of the house. Through an open doorway sees: A young, chillingly calm NANNY, watching him. The Baby fu in her arms. Milo smiles, keeps moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Second Houseman follows the trail of Mondrians. He sees Mondrians in two different directions. He hesitates, pick direction, keeps moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first Houseman moves through the Guests, toward Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo has finally made it. Sitting at Gary's work station, slips a CD-ROM into the PC. It floods with text. The musi echoes from far off. The entire wall behind him is filled with a Mondrian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Linder chats, the first Houseman sidles up to Gary,  whispers in his ear. We see Gary smile, excuse himself. H and Alice share a look as he moves off. We go with Gary. His smiles fades instantly. He pushes th Guests, who thank him for hosting such a brilliant "do;" hardly hears them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo writes frantically on his tiny pad, copying from the screen: LONGITUDE - 77 Degrees 03 Minutes 58 Seconds East LATITUDE - 38 Degrees 55 Minutes 14 Seconds South

dialogues.speaker: ALTITUDE
dialogues.text: He flips the page, begins entering the fixes for the next satellite. Thinking he's heard something, he looks up. Nobody's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Houseman turns in several directions, confused the trail of Mondrians. Passing into the next room, he ru into a Third Houseman, also confused. Each follows a diff Mondrian, in a different room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike the Housemen, Gary doesn't follow the paintings. H moves swiftly, seems to know where Milo is.

dialogues.speaker: GARY'S WORKROOM
dialogues.text: Milo still working...

dialogues.speaker: PARTY ROOM
dialogues.text: Alice looks up at the digital painting: still a Bosch. He face sets grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo clicks, closing the window. Concentrating, he doesn' see what we see on the wall behind him: the Mondrian drai away... And the wall fills up with the hellish Bosch trip After a moment, Milo senses something. Gary stands in the doorway. Watching him. Milo doesn't  breathe. Gary crosses the room, eyes locked with Milo's. Gary comes behind Milo. He reads the screen. It's filled  with text, whatever Milo loaded in when he sat down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading the screen) "Dear Lisa. I've enjoyed working  with you. I'd be lying if I didn't  say I find you attractive. But in my  heart I know that Alice..." (he looks up) You left my party to send E-mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't do it at work cause of  security or at home for -- obvious  reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary stares at Milo. He looks skeptical. The party music  floats in from afar as the moment stretches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could've handwritten it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not much good at handwriting. Or  parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's right. You're "clueless."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hangs there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary, I'm sorry if I was rude --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Houseman sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything OK, Mr. Boyd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. (when he's gone) Is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see what's hanging on the wall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks over. Milo looks over. Among the framed  commendations, awards, degrees we see Milo's childhood  program, written on Outpost 1.0. Gary has had it framed. Milo absorbs it. Even now, he feels something for Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you know what you mean to me.  Not just because of what you're doing.  Because of who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do know, Gary. I feel the same  way. I thought I was coming here for  a job. But it's meant a lot more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo smiles almost tenderly. He doesn't know if Gary buys it. Perhaps if he could see Gary's eyes. But they're obsc by Bosch's writhing bodies, reflected on his eyeglasses. Gary moves away from Milo, he stands over the table with art books, vaguely looks through one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will you have a Beta version?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo wonders: does he know? He picks his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pretty close. But when I wrote  the last contact switches, it wiped  out a piece of the content filer.  You know what it's like, writing  software.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do know. You focus on the big  problem. But somewhere down the chain,  something breaks down. Something  gets destroyed. At first it's  upsetting. You feel you've lost  control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary puts down the book. Something in his tone draws Milo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you have to remind yourself: it's  just the process. Something's always  lost along the way to anything  worthwhile. Some little bug, some  glitch. 'Can't get bogged down in  that, you're doing something other  people could never do. They lack the  imagination, the brain, the nerve.  Let them fret about every unforeseen  consequence. You have to solve the  problem. That's who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a confession? A plea for understanding? Or just a pep-talk to keep Milo focused on Skywire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the car, Milo and Alice pull away from the lights and  limos in icy silence. Several beats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna tell me where you went?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to see the Skywire model in  Gary's office. You know. Just to  hold it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. She stares ahead, out the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you having an affair, Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd better have his story straight with Gary and Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. I sent an E-mail to somebody,  just now. To tell her how I feel  about you. (looks at her) You know I'm clueless, without you.  You know I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting tears) Just shut up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is she faking it? Has he lost the trust of all of them He's afraid, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move in on the building, past Kids playing in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the children's shouts OS. Short, with a fingerpri kit, is dusting the keyboards. Len stands over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the backslash, the colon, keys  kids don't use but geeks do. (looking around,  perplexed) What would Milo want in here, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know. 'Just they don't trust me  with it. So we'll get the evidence,  first, ask questions later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the balustrade, in the dimness, Milo stands with Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he know you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suspects I know something. I think  he was sort of -- explaining himself  to me, in case I do. (he breathes) We have to go in tonight. I'm two  hours from a Beta version. (knows she won't like  it) But I've gotta go home for an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She called to apologize. I said I  was pulling an all-nighter. She said  then come home just to say Hi. Which  I always do when we fight, it's  suspicious if I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point the worst thing I could  do is anything out of the ordinary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, worried, then takes a disk out of her  backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the interface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes it. They kiss. She watches him go, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Milo comes up the path, he sees Alice in the kitchen. He opens the front door, steps in. She comes from the kit in an apron, wiping her hands. The apron is spattered, he hair is askew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a mess! I got this Hunan cookbook,  since we're always afraid for you to  eat in Chinese restaurants. I've  been mincing things into teeny-tiny  pieces all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles to hide his terror. Is she killing him now? Or  just testing his reaction? Or is it a sincere overture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me! I'm gonna change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she turns away, we see the fear on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice pulls into a dress.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Milo, at the stove, sniffs at the food that simmers in a  wok. He grabs a a spoon, examines it; but it's minced too fine to discern one ingredient from another.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alice pulls her hair back with a ribbon...

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Milo churns the garbage in the wastebasket, reads the lab on a jar, the label on a can...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Alice applies blush-on.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Milo goes through the spice cabinet...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Milo paces. He stops when she comes from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he smiles) You look beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Give me a goodbye kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you. You're gonna run back to  work right after dinner. I want my  kiss now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either she's the most cold-blooded woman in the world, or He takes her in his arms, kisses her long and hard -- as his life depended on it. When he releases her, she preten to swoon. She backs toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right back.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Camera is positioned on the counter, just behind the big  bowl as Alice spoons the food into it... She sprinkles on some final ingredient, also minced.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Milo's fingers drum the table top...

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Alice picks up the dish. We don't see her face.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DISH
dialogues.text: We hold the dish out in front of us. The food shines in t light, a poisonous yellow gleam. We move from kitchen to  dining room, slowly, deliberately... Milo comes into view beyond the dish, wearing a forced sm We come all the way to the table with the dish, where Ali sets it down. She sits. Milo, still vamping, pours wine. He picks up hi fork. Stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mind churns furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't we have any chopsticks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she's gone, he flips his left arm over and drags the tines of his fork against it, making score-marks, like th used by allergists to test for sensitivity. He dabs the sauce onto the tracks, wipes it clean. He sta at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice roots through ladles, bottle openers, cheese grater spatulas. At the bottom of the drawer, she finds two pair of take-out chopsticks, wrapped in white paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo looks from his watch to his arm -- no reaction yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) One more minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But here's Alice. She slips into her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unwraps the chopsticks rather slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...wanna savor this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna get cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Wait. A toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just afraid to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, picks up her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They toast. She sips her wine. He sips his. He wants  desperately to glance at his inner arm once more. But she watching him, waiting for him to eat. He picks up the chopsticks, gathers up a tiny bite. She  watches keenly. He brings the food to his mouth, passes i between his lips, swallows. He closes his eyes, ostensibly to savor the food, in fact bracing for a paroxysm. She watches him expectantly -- either for his verdict on food, or for the first fatal spasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice cracks) It's great. It's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grins. She takes a bite. The moment she looks away, h turns over his arm to get a look, face full of fear. The tracks are still flat, there's no redness. He shovels large bite into his mouth, ecstatic to be alive. Then ano bite, greedy with life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot and Len are in a high-tech office. On a monitor, we see a blown-up image of a fingerprint taken from Milo's  keyboard; Milo's name is printed under it. In a second window, other fingerprints flash by: thousand of prints lifted off keyboards in the Day Care. Shrot waits for a match to click in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo scrolls his Skywire code, concentrating intensely. T he feels some stickiness on his thumb and forefinger. He  rubs them together, peers at his keys. Dolly-zoom in on a trace of fingerprint powder. Fear seizes Milo. He ejects his the Skywire CD -- it is a bright silver color, with a Skywire logo on it -- slips i in an equally distinct silver (CD) jewel-case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo smiles at Desi as he moves up the hall. He almost bu into Gary's Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, hi! How was the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! Great! Thanks for asking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues up the hall. He ducks into the service hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot watches as The computer produces an alarm-like buzzing. The second w locks onto the matching print. The prints flash in unison garishly confirming the match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo races along the tunnel that leads from #20 to the Da Care...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot punches a number on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You calling Phil and Randy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo climbs the stairs, fumbles with the swipecard, enter the Day Care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Len is at the console. On a security monitor, he has call up video from a moment ago: Milo hurrying up the hall, al running into Gary's Secretary. Shrot has an eye on the video as he speaks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's left his office, we think he's  gone back to the Day Care for some  reason. Can you tell me why, Gary? (he listens) Whatever you say. (hangs up angrily) Wants to consult with Phil. Was it  Phil's idea to run the fingerprints?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot straps on his service revolver as he heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to catch up) Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo is under the table, detaching one of the the black  plastic data towers that contain the "primers," stored  surveillance material, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil hangs up the phone. He turns to Randy, who is with t two men: the blond GUNTHER, the pale-eyed RIMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the Day Care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo carefully detaches a second data tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot and Len hurry out of the building, toward the Day C across the quad. Len is ill-at-ease:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, I'm a programmer, not a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his haste, Shrot doesn't even hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther, Riman & Randy head down the service hallway, route to the bomb shelter stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo, lugging one bulky black data tower under each arm  (wondering if he should just ditch one) gets as far as th main, colorfully-carpeted room -- Shrot is there, gun drawn. Len stands just behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're better off not knowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot thinks he's being mocked, as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo sets down one of the towers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're surveilling programmers from  in here. They steal their code.  Sometimes -- I know this sounds insane --  sometimes they kill one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot looks skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They let me break into 21. 'Cause  there's nothing in there. You know  they've been keeping things from  you. 'Getting in the way when you  try t'do your job. That's why you  never told 'em your suspicions about  me. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrot doesn't deny it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you had I'd be dead now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milo's sincerity is striking. Shrot cogitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been following your gut all  along. Please don't stop now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunther, Riman and Randy climb the metal stairs, turn at landing, climb some more. When they get to the next landing, Riman opens the door.  They enter

dialogues.speaker: THE DAY CARE
dialogues.text: Hearing voices inside, Gunther draws a gun; they move for stealthfully. They enter the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randy sees: Shrot and Len.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
